title: 111_s147
content:
The Act titled "Lawful Interrogation and Detention Act" defines the term "intelligence community" and addresses the closure of the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay. The "Lawful Interrogation and Detention Act" mandates the closure of the Guantanamo Bay detention facility within a year. Detainees must either be charged with a violation of law and transferred to a secure facility in the US or transferred internationally before the closure. The "Lawful Interrogation and Detention Act" requires transferring detainees from Guantanamo Bay to an international tribunal under UN authority or to their country of citizenship, following legal and international obligations. If deemed safe, detainees can be transferred based on joint assessment by the Secretary of Defense and Director of National Intelligence. The "Lawful Interrogation and Detention Act" mandates transferring detainees from Guantanamo Bay based on joint assessment by the Secretary of Defense and Director of National Intelligence. If no security threat is found, detainees must be released. The President must report to Congress on the implementation plan within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The "Lawful Interrogation and Detention Act" does not consider subsection (b) as an entry into the US for immigration status. It does not grant additional detention authority and does not change existing authorities for individuals in US custody. SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON INTERROGATION TECHNIQUES: Individuals in custody of intelligence community personnel must only undergo interrogation techniques authorized by the US Army Field Manual on Human Intelligence Collector Operations.

SEC. 5. PROHIBITION ON INTERROGATIONS BY CONTRACTORS: The CIA Director cannot allow contractors to conduct interrogations, which must be carried out by CIA employees.

SEC. 6. NOTIFICATION OF THE INTERNATIONAL COMMITTEE OF THE RED CROSS: The CIA must notify the International Committee of the Red Cross during interrogations. SEC. 6. NOTIFICATION OF THE INTERNATIONAL COMMITTEE OF THE RED CROSS: The head of an intelligence community element detaining an individual must inform the International Committee of the Red Cross and provide access to the detainee in line with Armed Forces practices. This does not grant authority to detain or affect other rights under international agreements or laws.
